IT is a falÅ¿e notion to Å¿uppoÅ¿e that governments are moÅ¿t firmly eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed when the liberty of the Å¿ubject, or of the citizen, is deÅ¿troyed. div.head: CHAPTER VI. Of RIGHTS peculiar to certain STATIONS and ABILITIES.
div.p: BESIDES thoÅ¿e rights, equally belonging to all, which have been above illuÅ¿trated, there are others, which, although they are founded on the diÅ¿tinctions of rank and fortune, or on the general Å¿ubordination which civil Å¿ociety requires, are nevertheleÅ¿s deducible from that notion of equality eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed in the firÅ¿t part of this EÅ¿Å¿ay.

I. II. Å¿um of exertion, and to diffuÅ¿e its influence over the whole. It is juÅ¿t, therefore, that thoÅ¿e who contribute in the moÅ¿t diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed degree to the common welfare Å¿hould enjoy a proportionable Å¿hare of honour and advantage, adapted to the peculiar manner in which their utility has been diÅ¿played. To deprive them of this would be to deÅ¿troy their relation to the community, and that equality which conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in the common obligation of all to contribute to its benefit, and to receive a proportionate return.

When riches, acquired by honeÅ¿t induÅ¿try, or enjoyed in virtue of thoÅ¿e laws which perpetuate property, whatever be its value and extent, enable their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ors to relieve want, to Å¿ooth affliction, to diffuÅ¿e around them a Å¿pirit of improvement, to encourage induÅ¿try, and to make their Å¿uperfluity circulate through the general maÅ¿s of the community, they confer on the opulent a juÅ¿t title to conÅ¿ideration and influence, in proportion to the Å¿uperior benefits they beÅ¿tow on all who are placed within the Å¿phere of their action. V. All men have an equal, though imperfect, right to thoÅ¿e offices of humanity which, while they coÅ¿t the performers of them little trouble,
are the Å¿weeteners of Å¿ocial intercourÅ¿e; and to the compaÅ¿Å¿ion and relief, of others, proportioned to their condition and circumÅ¿tances, when they are overpowered by diÅ¿treÅ¿s and calamity.
